acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute

acute_toxicity_dermal.hazard_statement: May be harmful in contact with skin
acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: It is based on rat dermal LD50= 2330mg/kg (RTECS, 2004).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: SPECIES: Rat; ENDPOINT: LD50;VALUE:170mg/kg; REFERENCE SOURCE: RTECS (2004)

carcinogenicity.rationale: As inorganic mercury compounds, it was out of the Category. Since it is classified into IARC Group 3 (IARC, 58, 1993) and ACGIH A4 (ACGIH-TLV, 2004).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available.

explosives.rationale: Not classified because of UNRTDG No. 1627, Class: 6.1, II and non-explosive solely, though the substance contains N-O bonds as chemical groups associated with explosive properties present. (Compounds with phosphorus or heated carbon are explosive.)

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

flammable_solids.rationale: It was judged as nonflammable from the description "about 70 degC (decomposition) of melting point" (Merck, 13th, 2001).

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: In ATSDR (1999), since it estimated that mercury and mercury compounds induced chromosomal abnormality to the animal somatic cell in an in vivo, they were set to Category 2.

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Not classified because of UNRTDG No. 1627, Class:6.1, PG II, though its is an oxidizing agent (ERG, Guide141, 2004, corresponding to Sax, 11th, 2004 and UNRTDG No. 1627)

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: It was judged to be nonflammable from the description "Melting point: about 70 degC (decomposition)" (Merck, 13th, 2001).

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Since the effect on generating (California EPA, Proposition 65 List of Chemicals, 2005) and reproductive (ACGIH-TLV, 2004) was indicated as mercury and mercury compounds or inorganic mercuries, it was considered as Category 2.

self_heating_substances.rationale: It was judged as nonflammability based on the statement with "melting point is about 70 degC (decomposition)" (Merck, 13th, 2001).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Not classified based on UNRTDG No. 1627 Class: 6.1, PGII

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Due to the description that it may irritate to the eye (HSFS, 1993), it was classified into Category 2B.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: From description with the possibility which indicates skin irritation in humans (DFGOT, vol.15, 2001[as inorganic mercury compounds]; HSFS, 1993), mild irritation was considered to be a certain thing, and it was set to Category 3.

skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
skin_sensitizer.rationale: Since metallic mercury and inorganic mercury compound (as Hg)  were made into those with skin sensitization (MAK/BAT, 2005; DFGOT, vol.15, 2001), they were set to Category 1.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Stable to water (slightly soluble in water)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (central nervous system, kidney)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Since it was described the effect on the central nervous systems and the kidney  of humans by inorganic mercury compounds in Priority 1 document (ACGIH-TLV, 2004;EHC, 118, 1991), it was classified into Category 1 (a central nervous systems, the kidney).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement:
Causes damage to organs (kidney)
May cause respiratory irritation (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: The substance was classified as Category 1 (kidneys) and Category 3 (airway irritant) based on the reports concerning humans in Priority 1 documents that the target organs of the substance in the inorganic mercury compound are the kidneys (DFGOT, vol.15, 2001), and the report of potential irritant properties to the respiratory system in a Priority 2 document (HSFS, 1993).
